doc.field: Fischer: Positive Assessment of Trip to Turkey

Federal Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer gave his two-day visit to Turkey a positive assessment. In his words, Berlin and Ankara had begun a new chapter in their relations. They had many common interests, he said, as do Europe and Turkey - it was harder and harder to keep them apart. He added that there was a great deal of agreement and that the two countries had similar ways of describing the problems. The federal government plans to help Turkey in its efforts to be formally granted member candidate status at the EU summit in Helsinki at the end of the year. Fischer also brought up Turkey's human rights record in his discussions and pressed for a peaceful settlement to their problem with the Kurds.

Federal Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder plans to visit Kosovo on Friday. He would be the first western head of state to visit the region since the end of the war in Yugoslavia. According to a statement made by his foreign advisor Steiner, a visit to the German KFOR unit in Prizren is on Schroeder's agenda. Schroeder also plans to meet with representatives of the Kosovo-Albanians, of the UN as well as of the Serbian minority in Kosovo.
Defective Medical Equipment Found in Rhineland-Palatinate

A state-wide inspection of health offices has shown that almost 40 percent of the medical equipment in hospitals in Rhineland-Palatinate are defective. Officials responsible for overseeing the branch found defects in one of every 10 pieces of equipment that were so severe that the equipment had to be shut down. Respirators, inhalators and anesthesia equipment, among others, were inspected. The officials also noticed that some doctors and nurses did not know enough about how to operate the equipment.

The German Post Office has rejected the accusation that they are offsetting losses from package delivery with their extensive monopoly with letters. Spokesperson for the Post Office Schaefer called the accusation absurd. The EU Competition Commission apparently has a different opinion. It is considering requiring the German Post Office to pay back billions in state subsidies.

The Federal Foreign Office has confirmed that 20 diplomatic missions will be closed. "Otherwise we will not be able to save 270 million DM in the next budget," said a spokeswoman for the Foreign Office. The Consulate General offices in Detroit and Seattle are among those slated for closure.
Telefonica Delays Decision on Bangemann's Job

The Spanish telephone company Telefonica will presumably wait until September to decide whether it will hire departing EU-Commissioner Martin Bangemann as an advisor. Telefonica was apparently reacting to the pending suit against Bangemann before the European Court. The FDP politician is accused of taking insider knowledge from Brussels with him to his new job. Bangemann was also responsible for the telecommunications sector for the European Union.

In the first five months of this year, more accidents have occurred on Germany's streets. However, the number of traffic-related deaths has decreased. The Federal Department of Statistics has determined that from January through May of this year 2,900 people died as a result of accidents - about 8 percent less than the same period of the previous year. If this trend continues, the number of traffic-related deaths could reach a record low.
Ulf Kirsten to Quit National Team After European Championship

Ulf Kirsten, a member of Germany's national soccer team, intends to end his international career after the European Championship next year. After that, Kirsten will only shoot goals for his own club, Bayer Leverkusen.
